posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked:
Hello, from team 564!

We’ve successfully integrated localization using limelights into our Robot this year, which is a big leap for us, but this is also our first year using Swerve.

Our position on the field using the Limelights is very accurate, but our odometry without is so far off that it negates the point of having vision.

We tested removing our Vision code, and driving forward 1 meter, and our Estimated pose was over by about 10 inches. This gets exponentially worse as we go further, off by about 100 inches as we go out 100 inches.

We tried looking into our TunerConstants.java file, but everything seems mostly correct, including the kCoupleRatio and our Drive Gear Ratio and Steer Gear Ratio.

Please help, I have tons of questions!

Should I be using drivetrain.getState().Pose to read our internal odometry?

What measurements does the CommandSwerveDrivetrain from CTRE use to feed the Pose Estimator, we don’t know what is off on our robot, so we can start by looking into whats being used for the measurements in the first place.

Does the Pose Estimator use the Pidgeon gyro?

Lastly, please let me know what additional information you need from me to help debug this issue!

Code Repository image 1920×2560 708 KB

image 1920×2560 708 KB

image 1920×2560 708 KB

image 1920×1440 402 KB

image 1920×1440 402 KB

image 1920×1440 402 KB

image 1920×1440 213 KB

image 1920×1440 213 KB

image 1920×1440 213 KB

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
AlexanderCarlisi:

Should I be using drivetrain.getState().Pose to read our internal odometry?

This is correct.

AlexanderCarlisi:

What measurements does the CommandSwerveDrivetrain from CTRE use to feed the Pose Estimator, we don’t know what is off on our robot, so we can start by looking into whats being used for the measurements in the first place.

It’s generally using the position of all 4 swerve wheels (angle via the CANCoder and distance turned via the internal drive motor encoder) as well as the robot yaw via the Pigeon.

AlexanderCarlisi:

Does the Pose Estimator use the Pidgeon gyro?

Yes.

My recommendation would be to go back through the TunerX Swerve Generator and double check all your numbers, and regenerate the TunerConstants.java file. Odometry has worked really well out of the box for us, and errors of the magnitude you’re seeing generally seem like some sort of unit error or incorrect wheel diameter.

posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked:
Sorry forgot to mention in the post, we tried this and the file was identical.

We re-measured everything from new, and ran through all the checks, this was the first thing I did when I noticed the odometry was off.

posts.name: Dalton
posts.cooked: How are you retrieving the distances? I suspect you have a unit issue in your code.

posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked:
In the image I posted, I drove forward at 1 m/s for 4 seconds, my drivetrain is pidtuned so accounting for acceleration my IRL measurement is reasonable.

I got my distance by looking at my X Pose (I drove forward robot relative), which was 5.567 meters, which i then converted to inches using google to see the Robot thinks I moved 219 inches forward, as opposed to the 129 inches IRL.

I got my pose using the CommandSwerveDrivetrain’s getState().Pose TunerConstants also handles a lot of the Unit conversions and most of that code is also locked behind the library.

posts.name: Dalton
posts.cooked: What was your starting pose position?

posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked:
[0, 0, 0], ran it on deploy

Same with the drive Encoder positions, power cycled first so the values are all zero, I even wrote code to reset them if they weren’t perfectly zero

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: What wheels are you using? The marks on the carpet look like black nitrile roughtop, is that correct?

posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked: The SDS MK4i Billet wheel, from AndryMark.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Seems silly, but are you 100% sure the gear ratio you expect is installed (as in verified correct by inspection). This would be a linear error (not an exponential one though).

posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked:
Quite possible this is the issue, I won’t be able to confirm until tomorrow though.

Any other ideas? I’ll be testing as much as I possibly can tomorrow.

posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked:
What would be your suggested way of figuring out if this is the issue?

Drive forward calculate the gear ratio, plug it into TunerConstants and see if that fixes it?

Also would this issue persist into the Steer Ratio too? We have noticed slight drift when driving forward, I have to PID Tune the rotation to drive straight, I’m unsure if that’s normal though.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Easiest way would be to check the order reciept if you have only ever purchased one ratio.

Next would probably be turn the robot on its side and rotate the wheel by hand (simulate driving forward) while disabled (i. e. exactly 10 turns), see how many rotations the motor goes in software. Then check that against the manufacture’s gear ratios table.

Steering drift is likely down to wheel alignment and is a seperate easily solved issue

posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked:
Turns out we’re an L1 gear ratio bot, not an L2 one!

Thank you for the assistance.

posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked:
Let me clarify, I jumped the gun on marking this as the solution.

We spent the day working on trying out the solutions proposed by the community. Immediately we found that our Drive Gear Ratio is incorrect, and that we’re closer to a L1 Gear Ratio than what we thought we were (L2).

The issue now though is that even with this new Gear Ratio we’re not accurate. The further we travel the further off we are.

At a certain point we started trying to solve for our gear ratio using the equation : ratio  = distance / (diameter * pi * rotations)

But doing so provided us with 2 vastly different ratios depending on the distance we went. One was about 8.3, and the other 8.7, as opposed to L1’s ratio being about 8.14.

What else could we be doing wrong?
We always use Pathplanner to drive straight for 2M 0.5 velocity and acceleration.  Then adjust the wheel size until it is accurate.

posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked: We tried this before hopping on the bus to head up to competition, and we found success in trying this out, thank you!
